titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Gerald Stern Papers, 1920s-2012 SC.2007.04
titlestmt.author: Debora A. Rougeux in 2009 and Jennifer Needham in 2015.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-04-11 10:07:55 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Gerald Stern, the first Poet Laureate of New Jersey and Chancellor of the American Academy of American Poets, was born in Pittsburgh, Pa., on February 22, 1925 to Polish and Ukrainian immigrant parents. He received degrees from the University of Pittsburgh (BA in Political Science 1947) and Columbia University (MA in English 1949). He was the author of over fifteen books of poetry, two collections of essays, a one verse play, and in 2014 he published a book of his drawings. In addition, he received a number of nationally recognized awards, including the 1998 National Book Award for This Time: New and Selected Poems.The collection consists of manuscripts of Stern's poems and essays, including associated material, as well as correspondence, drawings, photographs, and audio and video recordings, making it a valuable resource in understanding Stern's creative process, influences in his life and his impact on national culture. Mr. Stern died on October 29, 2022 in Bronx, New York

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired from Gerald Stern on November 27, 2007. Additional materials acquired in January 2014.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collecton is organized into twelve series, as described below:
Series I. Poetry and Other Works
Series II. Articles, Essays, Lectures, Workshops and Other Projects
Series VIII. Poems, Essays, etc. for and about Gerald Stern

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Gerald Daniel Stern was born February 22, 1925 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. His parents, Harry and Ida Barach Stern, were Jewish immigrants from the Ukraine and Poland, respectively, who lived on Wylie Avenue in the city's Hill District, but later moved to an apartment on Beechwood Boulevard in the heavily Jewish neighborhood of Squirrel Hill. The second of two children, Stern was deeply affected by the death of his older sister, Sylvia, from cerebrospinal meningitis when he was eight years old. Stern attended Pittsburgh public schools, graduating from Taylor Allderdice High School in 1942. He was then admitted to the University of Pittsburgh, where he majored in English and was a member of the Men's Debating Association and Men's Glee Club. He received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Pitt in 1947 and a Master of Arts degree from Columbia University in 1949. He did post-graduate study at the Universit√© de Paris (1949-1950) and at Columbia University (1950-1952), but never completed the coursework necessary for a Ph.D. On September 12, 1952, Stern married Patricia Miller, with whom he has two children, David and Rachel. Stern and his wife divorced in the late 1980s.

Stern served in the United States Army Air Corps in 1946 and 1947. From 1951 to 1953, he was an English teacher and later principal at Lake Grove School, Long Island, N.Y. In 1954, during a tour of Europe with his wife Pat, he taught at Victoria Drive Senior Secondary School in Glasgow, Scotland. Upon returning to the United States in 1956, Stern accepted the position of instructor in Temple University's English Department, where he taught until 1963. From 1963 to 1967, he served as an assistant professor in the English Department at Indiana University of Pennsylvania, and from 1968 to 1982 he was a professor at Somerset County (later known as Raritan Valley) Community College in Somerville, N.J. During this latter period, he also conducted poetry workshops at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., (1975-1978) and Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y. (Spring 1977), as well as serving as a visiting professor at the University of Pittsburgh (Fall 1978) and Columbia University (1980). Stern also acted as literature consultant to both New Jersey's and Pennsylvania's Council of the Arts, as well as coordinator of the Pennsylvania Poetry in the Schools Program (1974-1978).

In 1982, Stern joined the faculty at the University of Iowa's Writers' Workshop, where he held the position of senior poet until 1995. He continued his visits to other universities, serving as Chairman of Creative Writing at the University of Alabama at Tuscaloosa (1984); Fanny Hurst Professor at Washington University in St. Louis, Mo. (1985); Visiting Professor at Bucknell University in Lewisburg, Pa. (1988); Holder of Bain Swiggert Chair at Princeton University (1989); Visiting Professor at New York University (1989); and Poet-in-Residence at Bucknell University (1994). In 2002, Stern co-founded the New England College's Master of Fine Arts (MFA) Program in Poetry with friend and former student Chard deNiord, and served as one of its inaugural faculty members. Most recently, Stern became a Distinguished Poet-in-Residence for the MFA Program in Poetry at Drew University, Madison, N.J., in January 2009.

Gerald Stern is the author of over fifteen books of poetry, two collections of personal essays, a one verse play, and a book of drawings. His first major published work was a long poem entitled "The Pineys," which first appeared in the Journal of the Rutgers University Library in 1969, when Stern was 44. Since then, he has given countless poetry readings and lectures throughout the United States and Europe and conducted several poetry workshops. He has been awarded numerous prestigious honors and prizes for his work. Among these are:

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Gerald Stern Papers, 1920-2012, SC.2007.04, Special Collections Department, University of Pittsburgh

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Gerald Stern Papers, 1920-2012, SC.2007.04, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Debora A. Rougeux in October 2009. A subsequent addition was processed between 2014-2015 by Jennifer Needham.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Gerald Stern Papers consist of manuscripts of his poems, essays, drawings, correspondence, publications in which his works appeared, photographs, and audio and/or video recordings of many of his readings, lectures and interviews. It is a valuable resource in understanding Stern's creative process, influences in his life, and his impact on national culture. The collection covers Stern's life from his early years through his writing and teaching career.
New materials were added to the collection in 2015. These materials are identified at the end of each applicable series or subseries as "2015 Addition."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains early and unpublished poems as well as materials related to published works, including notes, rough drafts, research material, original manuscripts, and page proofs. In this series are nineteen subseries; the first comprises early and/or unpublished poems while the remainder for each of Stern's published works. Within subseries 2-16, poems are arranged in the order in which they appear in the published work.
New material was added to this series in 2015 and is organized alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains early and/or unpublished poems, mostly unfinished, and notes, which range in date from 1940 to 1992.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: In 1969 Stern's first major published work, The Pineys, was published in the Journal of the Rutgers University Library. The entire issue was dedicated to this lengthy poem about the people who reside in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey. It would later be included inTwo Long Poems along with "Father Guzman," published in 1990.
The subseries includes Stern's research, notes, various drafts (one of which completely handwritten in pencil), typescripts, and photographs.

did.unittitle: Proof pages from Journal of the Rutgers University Library
Copy of The Pineys as it appeared in The Journal of the Rutgers University Library, XXXII, no. 2 (1969): 41-80

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Rejoicings, published in 1973, was a collection of Stern's early poetry written between 1966 and 1972. Many of these poems were included in his first book of poetry, The Naming of Beasts, published by Cummington Press in 1972.

Each folder contains notes and drafts for each of the poems, organized according to the order they appear in the book. The subseries also includes various typescripts, correspondence with publishers, reviews, and publicity.

did.unittitle: His Animal is Finally a Kind of Ape
On the Far Edge of Kilmer
When I Have Reached the Point of Suffocation
Burst of Wind between Broadway and the River
Correspondence with Arthur Vogelsang of Metro Book Co.
Typescript (2 copies) for Cummington Press edition of Naming of Beasts
Page Proofs from Cummington Press edition of Naming of Beasts
Copyright Certificate for Naming of Beasts
Rejoicings: Selected Poems / Gerald Stern. Fredericton, N.B.: Fiddlehead Poetry Books, 1973.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Stern's work became widely recognized after the 1977 publication ofLucky Life, which was that years Lamont Poetry Selection of the Academy of American Poets and was nominated for a National Book Award.

The first part of the subseries includes drafts of individual poems and research notes, organized according the order they appear in the publication. These are then followed by materials that document the books publication and include proofs, reviews, and correspondence with various publishers.

did.unittitle: Let Me Please Look into my Window
Burying an Animal on the Way to New York
Blue Skies, White Breasts, Green Trees
Sometimes When I Close my eyes
God of Rain, God of Water
Correspondence with Spring Church Book Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Red Coal, published in 1981, earned Stern the Melville Caine Award.

The subseries consists of notes and drafts for individual poems, organized according to the order they appear in the book. The subseries also includes publication information, like correspondence with publishers and various proofs.

did.unittitle: List of poems for possible inclusion
Correspondence with Spring Church Book Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: "Father Guzman," was Stern's first verse play originally published inThe Paris Review in 1982 and later published in 1990 as Two Long Poems, which also included The Pineys.
The subseries includes research materials, notes, drafts, proofs, correspondence, and a playscript.

did.unittitle: Proof Pages for Two Long Poems

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes materials related to Paradise Poems, published in 1984 by Random House. Materials include notes and drafts for individual poems, organized according to the order they appear in the book. Following the individual poems are notebooks, correspondence with publishers, and proofs and galleys that include Stern's notes and corrections.

did.unittitle: In Memory of W. H. Auden
It's Nice to Think of Tears
Dubuque Street, and , Saying the First Words

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials related to Stern's Lovesick, published in 1987 by Harpercollins and includes notes and drafts for individual poems, organized according to the order they appear in the publication. Following individual poems are notebooks, reviews, correspondence with publishers, and galleys and proofs that include Stern's notes and corrections.

did.unittitle: All I Have Are the Tracks
I do a Piece From Greece
I Sometimes Think of the Lamb

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Leaving Another Kingdom, published in 1990 by Harpercollins was a collection of previously published poems. The subseries includes only a typescript, proof, and a galley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This suberies includes materials related to Stern's 1993 collection of poetry, Bread Without Sugar, published by W.W. Norton and Co. The poem "Bread Without Sugar," was first published in 1991 by Sutton Hoo Press. Sutton Hoo was a fine press publisher founded in Iowa City in 1989. The publication of his long poem would be their first.

The subseries includes notes and drafts of individual poems, orgainzed according the order they appear in the book, follwed by reviews, correspondence with publishers,typescripts, proofs, and galleys--many of which include Stern's notes and corrections.

did.unittitle: Her Right Eye Catches the Lavendar
His Song of the Green Willow
Those Things, and, If the Lark Had Thorns
Someone Will Do It for Me
Correspondence with W.W. Norton & Company, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Stern's ninth collection of poetry, Odd Mercy, published in 1995 by W.W. Norton included 22 poems.

The subseries includes notes and drafts of individual poem, organized according to the order they appear in the book, followed by notebooks, reviews, correspondence with publishers, and a typescript, proof, and galley which include Stern's notes and corrections.

did.unittitle: The Jew and the Rooster Are One
Correspondence with W.W. Norton & Company, Inc.

unittitle.title: This Time: New and Selected Poems

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: National Book Award winner, This Time, was published in 1998 and included selections from his previous seven books of poetry and 14 new poems. The subseries mostly includes drafts of the new poems and various publication materials, like proofs, as well as materials realted the publication's National Book Award for Poetry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes one galley for the Polish translation of Stern's poem Underground Dancing, translated by Adam Szyper and published in 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes materials related to Last Blue, published in 2001 by W.W. Norton and Co., and includes notes and drafts for individual poems, according to the order they appear in the book. This is followed by various typescripts, proofs, and galleys, organized according to the publishing process, and include Stern's notes and corrections.
New materials were added to the subseries in 2015 and include additional typescripts and a galley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes materials related to American Sonnets, published in 2003 by W.W. Norton and Co., and includes notes and drafts for individual poems, according to the order they appear in the book. This is followed by notebooks, correspondence with pubishers, and various proofs and galleys, organized according to the publishing process, and that include Stern's notes and corrections.

did.unittitle: How a Word Can Breathe, and, September, 1999

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes materials related to Stern's collection of personal essays, What I Can't Bear Losing, published in 2004 by W.W. Norton and Co., and includes notes and drafts for individual essays, organized according to the order they appear in the book. This is followed by notebooks, correspondence, and typescripts, organized according to the publishing process, and that include Stern's notes and corrections.
The book was republished in 2009 with the addition of seven new essays. Materials related to the 2009 edition are located under the subseries "2015 Addition."

did.unittitle: What I Have to Defend, What I Can't Bear Losing
Correspondence with W.W. Norton & Company, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes materials related to Stern's 15th book of poetry, Everything is Burning, published in 2006 by W.W. Norton and Co., and includes notes and drafts for individual poems, according to the order they appear in the book. This is followed by notebooks, various typescripts, proofs, and galleys, organized according to the publishing process, and include Stern's notes and corrections.

did.unittitle: Those Saucer that Were His Eyes
The Trent Lott, The McNamara Blues
Correspondence with W.W. Norton & Company, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Not God After All, published in 2004 by Autumn House Press, feature petite narratives accompanied by drawings by Sheba Sharrow. The subseries includes drafts, notes, reviews, publication information, and proofs.

did.unittitle: Drafts of A Fire I Understand (original title)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Stern's long poem, The Preacher was published as part of the Quarternote Chapbook Series by Sarabade Books in 2007. The subseries mostly contains various typescripts with notes, correspondence, and proofs.

did.unittitle: Ecclesiastes as witness: a personal essay

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes materials added to the collection in 2015 and is divided into sections for books published between 2008-2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains materials related to Stern's collection of poetry, Save the Last Dance, pubished in 2008 by W.W. Norton and Company. Included are notes and drafts of individual poems, organized alphabetically, followed by typescripts, proofs, and galleys, organized according to the publication process.

did.unittitle: Save the Last Dance for Me
Notebook of Rough Drafts and Notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: What I Cant' Bear Losing was originally published in 2003. This subseries contains materials related to the 2009 edition which included seven new essays. The subseries includes drafts of new essays, research notes, notebooks, and typescripts, proofs, and drafts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Early Collected Poems is a collection of Stern's first six books of poetry, including: Rejoicings, Lucky Life, The Red Coal, Paradise Poems, Lovesick, and Bread Without Sugar. The subseries mostly includes foul matter from Norton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This section inlcudes materials related to Stern's collection of essays,Stealing History, published in 2009 by Trinity University Press and mostly contains Stern's research which consists of printouts of Wikipedia articles, organized alphabetically. Only those Wikipedia articles marked with Stern's notes were retained. For unmaked articles, a list was created and included in the series. The series also includes notes and various drafts of sections and full manuscripts, organized according to the publishing process.
Note that there is a notebook for In Beauty Bright that contains drafts for Stealing History, located in following subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes

Note that drafts of In Beauty Bright are also located within a notebook of rough drafts for the unpublished poem "I", which follows this subseries.

Articles, Essays, Lectures, Workshops and Other Projects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials related to Stern as editor of various anthologies and his column, Notes From a River, feature in the American Poetry Review from 1979-1984. Also incuded are research and drafts of various articles and essays written by Stern and materials pertaining to lectures,talks, workshops, and interviews published in various journals.
New material was added to this series in 2015 and can be found within each subseries as "2015 Addition."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains drawings done mostly by Stern from the 1950s through the 1990s. This does not include the drawings that appeared in his 2014 book of drawings, Dancing with Tears in My Eyes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence to and from Stern, arranged alphabetically and by type of correspondent (note that Stern designated these "types").
New material was added to this series in 2015 and is desidated within the applicable subseries as "2015 Addition."

did.unittitle: Letter from Summers to his wife
Typescript of chapters 1-10 of The Swindle

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains requests for Stern's poems for journals and for publication in anthologies, reviews of other poets' works, and requests for participation in various projects and events.

did.unittitle: American Poetry Review - Stephen Berg to G.S.
American Poetry Review - G.S. to Stephen Berg

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains publicity and advertising material from the early 1970s to 2007 and is arranged by date into three subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Stern's personal files of letters and publicity about readings, including posters. Also included are appointment books which demonstrate his relentless public reading schedule. The series is arranged chronologically.
New materials were added in 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains general poetry information and projects with which Stern has been involved and includes directories, articles, tapes, letters, talks, essays, political organizations, colleges, temporary college positions, prize judging, laureateships, radio appearances, etc. It is arranged in the order in which it was received.
New material was added to this series in 2015 and is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes works for and about Stern written by other authors, including poems, essays, parodies and translations of Stern's work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains manuscripts written by other writers that were sent to Stern for comment or review. Materials are separated into subseries according to those that contain or do not contain Stern's notes.
New material was added to this series in 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Included in this series are magazines, periodicals, and anthologies that Stern's works or reviews of his work appeared. The series is arranged by type of publication into two subseries: magazines and periodicals and anthologies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes personal photos of Stern and his family and friends, as well as professional author photos and photos of Stern with other well-known poets. It includes some slides and negatives, as well as prints. The series is divided by topic into three subseries, with dates ranging from the 1930s through 2007.

did.unittitle: Calendars of Rebecca Martin and family
Gerald Stern with other well-known poets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains media material from projects in which Stern was involved and readings he gave of his poetry, as well as interviews and lectures. The series is arranged into four subseries; the first three by type of event, the last by form.

did.unittitle: Somerset Community College - The Making of a Poem
New England College - MFA Poetry Program
